Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Effects of anthropogenic habitat fragmentation on primate movement patterns and dispersal

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past several thousand years, human expansion into tropical forests and the associated transformation of landscapes into patchworks of forested, agricultural, and urban habitats has had a negative impact on primate populations and led to increases in direct conflict between humans and wild, nonhuman primates. However, despite this long history of contact, the influence of human (anthropogenic) factors on primate evolutionary trajectories is not fully understood. This project will examine how anthropogenically-fragmented landscapes affect gene flow, genetic structure, and functional connectivity among wild populations of the silvery-brown tamarin, a charismatic and endangered primate from the Rio Magdalena valley in northern Colombia. The study will strengthen long-term international collaborations between US and Colombian researchers and help bolster relationships between researchers, the local community, and the state environmental corporation, which will further support the conservation of this endangered primate. It will also provide research, training, and mentorship opportunities for a female graduate student and undergraduates, thereby promoting and engaging greater participation of underrepresented constituencies in STEM disciplines.

Tamarins are small-bodied monkeys with relatively short generation times, and across their geographic range they are subject to ongoing anthropogenic landscape changes. At the same time, they show a high degree of mobility and ability to survive in human-modified habitats, resulting in their sharing space with humans and making tamarins ideal models for understanding the evolutionary consequences of habitat fragmentation. Using next-generation genomic techniques, this project will type tens of thousands of markers from across the nuclear genome for dozens of individual tamarins to determine how natural and anthropogenic factors together shape patterns of genetic variation at the landscape level. This will be one of the first genomic studies of population structure in wild primates and one of the first to explicitly examine the effects of human-induced habitat change. The genetic data and results will be disseminated through scientific journals and presentations and will be given to environmental agencies for future implementation of conservation actions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We investigated the effects of habitat fragmentation on the dispersal and movement patterns of the silvery brown tamarin. Tamarins, like many primate species, have been strongly affected by human activities. Hunting, selective logging, intensive agriculture, and cattle ranching all contribute to the degradation and fragmentation of tamarin habitat and are considered the main threats to their survival in the wild. Habitat loss and fragmentation not only decrease the amount of forest available in the landscape, but also reduce the degree to which different forest patches are connected and thus the ability of tamarins to move from one place to another. As the dispersal of individuals is restricted, the rate and amount of genetic information that can be exchanged among populations (i.e., gene flow) decreases, which ultimately leads to a loss of genetic diversity and an increase in the genetic differentiation among populations. Therefore, it is very important not only important to reduce habitat destruction, but also to understand how gene flow, population structure, genetic diversity, and species survival are affected by such habitat transformations.

Our project had three main goals: 1) to characterize the population structure of silvery brown tamarins in a highly fragmented landscape in Colombia, 2) to examine the effects of landscape fragmentation on dispersal and gene flow among tamarin populations, and 3) to document the degree of connectivity among fragments across this landscape.

To address these issues, we obtained DNA samples from 78 individuals silvery brown tamarins from 10 different populations and 21 social groups  and collected data on characteristics of the landscape and forests these groups inhabited. Additionally, we developed and standardized a novel method for identifying thousands of molecular markers distributed along the genome of the silvery brown tamarin.

Using a combination of analytical methods, we identified five genetically distinct populations of tamarins that coincide with three major geographic areas located in the northern, central, and southern distribution of the species. The observed population structure was associated with geographic distance, with closer populations being genetically more similar to one another than more distant populations. Our results demonstrate the utility and power of using thousands of molecular markers for resolving primate genetic structure at fine spatial scales. Moreover, our results provide useful information for understanding the evolutionary history of tamarins as well as new insight into how genetic variation in this species is distributed across a heterogeneous landscape.

Using GIS to model connectivity among the patches of forest that tamarins inhabit, we were able to identify what patches are key to tamarin dispersal as well as to pinpoint what areas of the landscape are critical for promoting such dispersal. We found that despite the fact that young, successional forests and cropland are not optimal habitat for tamarins, they nonetheless provide important routes for tamarin movement. These results are important as they allow us to design management plans that promote the conservation of tamarins within human-dominated landscapes.

Over the course of our project, we created six field assistant positions for young women scientists from Colombia. All received training and practice in behavioral and ecological data collection, database management, and GIS analysis and developed their undergraduate theses using data collected in this project, thus also gaining analytical and writing skills. Additionally, one University of Texas undergraduate was trained in basic lab techniques and in bioinformatic analysis of next generation sequencing data.

Lastly, as a result of a memorandum of understanding between UT and the Universidad de Antioquia in Colombia (UDEA), one Colombian doctoral student conducted a six-month internship at UT and was trained in next-generation sequencing methods as well as in the use of bioinformatics to analyze genome-wide data. We are currently collaborating with her and other researchers from UDEA to understand hybridization patterns of tamarins in captivity and to inform their captive management.

Throughout this project, we have strived to make our research relatable, accessible, and relevant to conservation practitioners in Colombia. Our goal was that the results from this study be used by environmental authorities to develop or complement conservation plans for tamarins in Colombia. Not only have we presented our data at national and international academic conferences, but we have also collaborated with Colombian NGOs, the environmental state corporation, and Colombian researchers to help design a national conservation plan for the silvery brown tamarin. We have disseminated our project results to the local community to raise stakeholders' awareness about the conservation status of tamarins. We also conducted six conservation workshops and three meetings with the local community and school to evaluate and understand community members' perceptions about tamarins and their habitats, and we organized several meetings with local cattle ranchers to discuss with them alternative ranching strategies that could benefit both cattle and tamarins. Working with the community, we identified opportunities to use the tamarin as a flagship species to increase tourism in the region.
